bestBHT.bht: This is the true turning unto the Lord; when laying away all fierceness and fury, we bow down our necks willingly to bear his yoke, and are ready to do whatsoever he commandeth us. Moreover, this is the beginning of well-doing, to ask the mouth of God; their labor is lost who think upon repentance without his word. Into Damascus, of all things which are appointed for thee, I said, what shall I do, Lord?

John Calvin: This is the voice of a tamed man, and this is the true turning unto the Lord; when laying away all fierceness and fury, we bow down our necks willingly to bear his yoke, and are ready to do whatsoever he commandeth us.
Moreover, this is the beginning of well-doing, to ask the mouth of God; for their labor is lost who think upon repentance without his word.
[God] teaches us that we must not grudge to hear him speak with the tongue of men.
Archibald T. Robertson: Into Damascus (εις Δαμασκον). In Acts 9:6 simply 'into the city' (εις την πολιν).
Of all things which (περ παντων ων). Hων, relative plural attracted to genitive of antecedent from accusative α, object of ποιησα (do).
Are appointed for thee (τετακτα σο). Perfect passive indicative of τασσω, to appoint, to order, with dative σο.
John Gill: And I said, what shall I do, Lord?....
